utterances: Yes.
Good afternoon.
Good afternoon.
Go ahead.

Oh, I was, I had told your associates that I was held captive by a sheriff's deputy in the 70s for four hours, who stopped me for speeding as presumably, but he took me down on a country road and held me for four hours and, you know, threatening me and it was an experience that made me realize that most people are never in a situation to be held against their will.

And you go to a place in your brain, you know, like an animal because, you know, on jobs when people are at work, they think, oh, I wish I could leave here but then you always can, you really can but to be held against your will, there's nothing that most people don't really ever experienced.
Could you imagine what it was like, again, you said it was for a few hours?
Four hours.
Fourteen months, 11 months, six years like these women in Colombia?
It is incomprehensible to me because I don't know how people, you know, do survive it.
I am - it's just - it's incomprehensible.
Hmm.
Thanks very much for the call.
You're welcome.
Bye-bye.
And Vincent Cochetel, that leads to a question: what did you learn?
What did you take out of this that you think is positive?
Thank you.
And so then you have to get it down the mountain, right?
Well, I think everyone has good inside himself, lots of resources that we ignore.
I mean, it's unfortunate that usually when you're confronted to extraordinary circumstances in life that you realize that you have the sort of capacity to resist and to make it through.
The thing what I learn at the end of the day I think it's like (unintelligible) is dead.
There are not that many things that matter in life.
There are really important things, I mean, there was a radical shift of some of the values when I came out.
John Limbert, what do you think you learned?
Agree.

I mean, what you think is what you think is important one day ceases to be important and all of those political considerations and all of this close analysis that I thought mattered didn't matter at all.
I mean, when it came down to this, when the Iranians holding us said that they wanted the shah back to release us, my first thought was that sounds reasonable to me.
I don't see any problem with that.
And then, if they shifted to $24 billion and some F14 parts, I said, well, I don't see anything wrong with that either.
That sounds very reasonable.
If they want Henry Kissinger in the bargain, I'll throw him in, too.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Let's see if we can get one last caller in.
This is Janet(ph).
Janet with us from Cincinnati, Ohio.
Yes.

Your sort of preempted my question a little bit but given the horrors that these men went through and you read about people, the times you go through terrible things and say at the end of it, it made me who I am today.
I guess I want to know would they not do - would they have chosen not to have had this happen to them?
Oh, if you go back and erase it, Vincent…
Basically, yeah.
…yeah, Vincent Cochetel, would you do that?
No, because I believe that I was there for a fair cause, the way people are suffering and there was a job to do, and I enjoy it with my team.
And if I had to do it again, I'll do it again.
Maybe I would take all the precaution, maybe I would work with different security measures around me.
I'm still working for the same organization today, but I think I'd learn some more personal values out of that.
I think I've learned to say things to people directly, less indirectly, you know?

In our society, sometime you don't dare to say to people thank you, you don't dare to say to people I love you or forgive me and all that when you know you're not going to be sure to see the people the day after.
You learn to take those shortcuts in life that make like much more enjoyable.
John Limbert, if you could tell us in 30 seconds, if you…
Well, I was - like Vincent, I was very proud of what I did as a Foreign Service officer but I must say, if I could have gone out and gotten that haircut this, that morning, I would've done so.
So, this was not my event of choice or preference.
Janet, thanks very much for the call.
Thank you.
And thanks to both of our guests.

Vincent Cochetel, a former hostage in Chechnya, held captive while working for the office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees where he continues to work as deputy director of the UNHCR's Division of International Protection Services, on the phone with us from his home in Switzerland.
Thanks very much for your time today.
Thank you.
And John Limbert, one of the 52 hostages held in Iran.
Appreciate your time today as well.
Thank you, Neal.
And he joined us from the studios of WUNC in Durham, North Carolina.
When we come back, we'll talk with an author, a science author, who found his words reprinted in a romance novel.
This is NPR News.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
In a moment, an update from St. Bernard's Parish, where residents are struggling to put their lives back together after Hurricane Katrina.
But first, health officials from the US and the United Nations began touring Southeast Asia today.
They're trying to raise awareness about the dangers that avian flu could pose to humans.
The UN is considering boosting worldwide production of a flu vaccine in case of a pandemic.
Dr. John Treanor is a professor of medicine with the University of Rochester School of Medicine, and he joins us now.
Dr.
Treanor, you've been testing a vaccine for the bird flu.
Where does that stand now?
Well, we have finished the immunizations of healthy adults, and we're now proceeding to test the vaccine in older adults who are healthy but over the age of 65 as well as in children.
And how does this vaccine differ from the regular flu vaccine that many people get at this time of year?

Well, it's really more similar than it is different, except, of course, that instead of containing the usual B, H1 and H3 that are in the typical flu shot, this shot contains H5, which is a kind of virus that causes bird flu.
I'm wondering if one gets the regular flu vaccine if that provides any sort of immunity for the bird flu vaccine.
It doesn't look like it.
There really is no close relationship between the kinds of flu that we get every year and that are in the regular flu shot and this bird flu virus, and that's what makes it so dangerous.
The bird flu virus, in terms of its antigens--the outer surface--is a very different animal than the regular flu viruses we're used to.
And if officials do decide to go ahead with the vaccine that's being tested right now for the bird flu, how long would it take before that vaccine is available?
Well, this year, honestly, they were a team that should have probably fallen apart last year.
They probably shouldn't have won.
They had a bunch of rookies in the lineup and on the pitching staff, and they somehow won again because the Mets had not yet ripened into the team that they became this year - the juggernaut.
The Phillies certainly had not become the team that some people had expected, and the Marlins had yet be blown up and built up again.
So last year really was a little bit more of a fluke than most of the Braves teams we were used to when they won 14 straight.
Here's an e-mail we got from Larry in Queens, NY.
The only possible response to the end of the Braves' streak of division titles, he writes, is let's go Mets.
We know where he's standing.
We're talking today with Alan Schwarz about the extraordinary run - 14 consecutive division championships for the Atlanta Braves.
You're listening to TALK OF THE NATION from NPR News.

And Alan, to what degree is the achievement of the Atlanta Braves - again, incredibly difficult to do in this era of free agency - but is it dimmed by the fact that amid all those championships, they only got one world series championship?
No, I don't think it has dimmed at all.

I mean, certainly everyone in my business has talked with a lot of the long-time Braves, whether it was Greg Maddux and Tom Glavine while they were there or John Smoltz, who's still there - Chipper Jones.
We've all talked to them about, you know, how proud they are or should be about winning all those titles and yet only coming away with one World Series ring in 1995.
And I think that it's an example of how much the playoffs really is a crapshoot, okay?
That's not a very popular thing to say.
Everyone likes to revere the Yankees for having won so many championships, and of course they earned them.

But a 162-game test of the regular season is really a lot more telling than a three out of five in the first round of the playoffs, or a four out of seven in the league championship series - which is where the Braves have typically ended their seasons for most of the past six years.
